In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

In Julia, you can define a function `clean_column` that cleans up column names as follows:

```julia
function clean_column(col::AbstractString)
    # Lowercase the string
    lowercase = lowercase(col)
    # Strip leading and trailing whitespace
    strip = strip(lowercase)
    # Replace spaces and hyphens with underscores
    cleaned = replace(strip, r"\s|-" => "_")
    return cleaned
end
```

This function takes an `AbstractString` as input and returns a lowercased, whitespace-stripped, and dash-to-underscore replaced version of the string. The regular expression `r"\s|-"` matches any whitespace character or hyphen.

You can use this function like so:

```julia
julia> clean_column("My Column")
"my_column"

julia> clean_column("  my column   ")
"my_column"

julia> clean_column("my-column")
"my_column"
```

Make sure to import the `replace`, `strip`, and `lowercase` functions from the standard library before using them:

```julia
using Base.String: lowercase, strip, replace
```

This ensures that you are using the versions of these functions defined in the `Base.String` module rather than any potential ambiguous definitions elsewhere in your code or in loaded packages.
